questions.text: Which of the following drugs are used in the closure of patent ductus arteriosus?
questions.solution:
NSAID's like ibuprofen and indomethacin are used in the medical management to induce closure of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

Patent ductus arteriosus is the failure of the closure of ductus arteriosus. It usually connects the pulmonary trunk to the aorta distal to left subclavian artery branching. It gives rise to a continuous murmur, which is heard throughout the cardiac cycle. It results in decreased oxygenated blood supply to the lower half of the body. It closes by itself in 2-4 weeks, unless it is large.

Medical management involves ruling out other causes of continuous murmur and any other duct dependent lesion. In the absence of either, prostaglandin inhibitor like Indomethacin or Ibuprofen may be given. But these are contraindicated in Necrotising enterocolitis (NEC). 

A recent edition of AIIMS neonatology protocol book says that paracetamol is equally effective as Ibuprofen and can be given in case NSAIDs are contraindicated.

Note:

  • Prostaglandin E1 is a ductal smooth muscle relaxant and is used to maintain an open ductus arteriosus in the newborn with ductal-dependent congenital heart disease.

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with irritability and cyanosis which subsides on crying. On examination, you are unable to pass a nasogastric tube and no mist formation is noted on the laryngeal mirror test. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of choanal atresia, the best next step would be to provide an oropharyngeal airway.

Choanal atresia is the persistence of the bucconasal membrane, unilateral is more common and may remain undiagnosed until adult life, bilateral atresia will present as a respiratory obstruction in the newborn. The initial clinical evaluation consists of placing a large laryngeal mirror under each nostril and checking for fogging, this is known as the laryngeal mirror test.

Diagnosis can be made by:

  • Presence of mucoid discharge in the nose
  • Absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge
  • Failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx
  • Putting methylene blue dye into the nose and checking its passage to the pharynx
  • Putting a radio-opaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral radiograph
  • CT in the axial plane 

Management: In bilateral atresia, emergency treatment is to provide an airway, which is done by McGovern's technique- (a feeding tube with a large hole that provides a good oral airway), this removes the need for tracheostomy. Definitive treatment is correcting the atresia either by transpalatal or transnasal approach, which is usually done at one and a half years of age.

Related Pearl: Choanal atresia

  • It is due to the persistence of bucconasal membrane which separates primitive oropharynx from the primitive nasopharynx
  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • 30% of cases are bony and 70% are mixed
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • C- Coloboma of the eye
    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.
  • CT scan is the best investigation

Image: Membranous, bilateral choanal atresia in a newborn

 

 

  • McGoverns technique- A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway
  • Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with a short history of facial oedema that has now progressed to total body swelling involving the face, abdomen, scrotum, and feet. Urinalysis revealed protein 4+ with no hematuria and a urine protein:creatinine ratio of 3. What is the initial treatment of choice for this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and investigations are suggestive of minimal change nephrotic syndrome and the initial treatment of choice is corticosteroids such as prednisolone.

Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years with a clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome with

  • heavy proteinuria
  • oedema
  • hypoalbuminemia
  • hyperlipidemia.

They show excellent response to steroid therapy. A daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate day dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks is recommended.

questions.text: A 5-day-old baby, born at 35 weeks gestation and weighing 1700 grams, is being evaluated for nutritional needs in the neonatal intensive care unit. What will be the recommended daily fluid intake for this baby?
questions.solution:
The daily fluid requirement for this 5-day-old child weighing 1700 g is 140 ml/kg/day (140–160 ml/kg/day).

Parenteral fluid in ml/kg/day: For neonates with a birthweight >1500 gm:

Body weight > 1500 g Fluid required per day
Day 1 60-80
Day 2 80-100
Day 3 100-120
Day 4 120-140
Day 5 140-160
Day 6 140-160

Parenteral fluid in ml/kg/day: For neonates with a birthweight <1500 gm:

Body weight < 1500 g Fluid required per day
Day 1 80-90
Day 2 100-110
Day 3 120-130
Day 4 130-150
Day 5 140-160
Day 6 150-170

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida delivers a preterm baby at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg. She is advised to hold her child as shown below.  Which of the following statements about this method is false?

choices.text: Safety and thermal protection provided by this method is comparable to incubators
Should be performed only by the mother

questions.solution:
Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver.

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components—

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

Evidence shows that-

  • It is at least equivalent to incubators, in terms of safety and thermal protection (measured by mortality)
  • Reduces severe morbidity by way of facilitating breastfeeding
  • Humanization of neonatal care
  • Promoted bonding between mother and child

Eligibiilty criteria for KMC:

It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birthweight babies. Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.

  • Birthweight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC
  • Birthweight 1200-1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation
  • Birthweight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth

All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC

Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breast in an upright position. The hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea.

The duration of KMC should be gradually increased from short sessions of more than one hour to 24 hours a day.

KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation.

Note: 

Incubatory care, feeding via nasal catheter, and prevention of infection are part of intensive care for low birthweight babies.

questions.text: The most common leukemia in children with Down syndrome is _____.
questions.solution:
The most common leukemia in children with Down’s syndrome is acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Children with Down syndrome are at increased risk of both acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Note:

  • The most common leukemia in Down's syndrome: is B-cell Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL)
  • The most common AML in Down's syndrome: is M7/megakaryoblastic

10% of neonates with Down's syndrome develop transient leukemia or myeloproliferative disorder. These features usually resolve within the 1st 3 months of life. However, they require close follow-up, because 20–30% will develop typical leukemia (often acute megakaryocytic leukemia) by 3 years of life (AML is more common during the first 3 years of life )

questions.text: A child suffering from steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the OPD for vaccination. Which of the following is true about vaccination in this child?

choices.text: All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule
All killed vaccines under NIS can be given
Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in acute phase
Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child’s sibling

questions.solution:
All killed vaccines can be given.

Live virus vaccines are administered with caution in children receiving corticosteroid therapy. They can be given to patients in whom the prednisone dose is below 1mg/kg daily or 2mg/kg on alternate days. If the patient is receiving corticosteroid-sparing agents (cyclophosphamide, cyclosporine), live virus vaccines are contraindicated.

Immunization of siblings/healthy household contacts with live vaccines is necessary to reduce the risk of infection transmission to the immunosuppressed child. Direct exposure to the gastrointestinal/respiratory secretions of the household contacts is avoided for about 3-6 weeks after vaccination. 

Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of the nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years and is characterized by heavy proteinuria, edema, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. Patients are either asymptomatic or present with peripheral edema. Renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the child fits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome.

They show excellent response to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone. A daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks is recommended.

Alternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistant patients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are as follows:

  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Calcineurin inhibitors: Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus
  • Mycophenolate
  • Levamisole
  • Rituximab (a chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD20)

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with a cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. The total leucocyte count is >50,000 cells/μL. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of paroxysm of cough, apnea, and leukocytosis (>50,000 cells/μL) in a neonate is suggestive of pertussis. Azithromycin is the recommended drug of choice for the treatment of pertussis in neonates (< 1 month of age).

Macrolides are recommended for the treatment of pertussis. Azithromycin is the drug of choice in all age groups, for treatment or postexposure prophylaxis. Post-exposure prophylaxis is given to household close contacts and high-risk contacts (infants, immunocompromised, pregnancy).

Other options:

Option B: Amoxicillin is not used for the treatment of pertussis due to its inefficiency in the nasopharynx.

Option C: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole) is recommended as an alternative for infants >2 months old and children who are allergic to macrolides.

Option D: Clarithromycin is an alternative drug that can be used in infants aged >2 months. In children less than 2 months of age, it is contraindicated due to the risk of kernicterus.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have movements as shown in the clip. His APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His blood sugar was within the normal range in the first 24 hours. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clip depicts neonatal seizure of focal clonic type.

A focal clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups of the limbs, face, or trunk, and-

  • Maybe unifocal or multifocal
  • May occur synchronously or asynchronously in muscle groups on one side of the body
  • May occur simultaneously but asynchronously on both sides
  • It cannot be suppressed by restraint

A focal tonic seizure is characterized by sustained posturing of single limbs, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, sustained eye deviation, cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.

Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. It cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.

Subtle seizures include transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, abnormal extremity movements (rowing, swimming, cycling, pedaling), fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in premature than in term babies.

WHO recommendations:

  • Clinically apparent seizures in the neonate should be treated if they last >3 minutes or are brief serial seizures.
  • If electroencephalography (EEG) is possible, all electrical seizures should also be treated, even in the absence of clinically apparent conditions.
  • In all neonates with seizures, hypoglycemia, CNS infection, and hypocalcemia should be ruled out before anti-epileptic drug treatment.

questions.text: The true statement regarding the trajectory of the growth curve of a neonate is:

choices.text: 10% of birth weight is lost in the 1st week of life
10% of birth weight increases in the 1st week
10% of birth weight is lost in the 1st 2 weeks of life

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding the trajectory of the growth curve of a neonate is that "10% of birth weight is lost in the 1st week of life".

In the first week after birth, newborns typically experience a temporary weight loss of around 10% after vaginal delivery and up to 12% after cesarean section. This initial decrease is primarily due to the elimination of excess fluid and limited early nutritional intake. As feeding progresses, colostrum gives way to higher-fat breast milk, and infants improve their ability to latch and suck effectively. Consequently, mothers become more adept at feeding techniques.

By the second week of life, most infants regain their birth weight or surpass it. Throughout the first month, infants typically gain about 30 grams (approximately 1 ounce) per day. This period marks the fastest phase of postnatal growth. Approximate daily weight gain is that : 0-3 months: 30 g/day; 3-6 months: 20 g/day; 6-9 months: 15 g/day; 9-12 months: 12 g/day.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the outpatient clinic with intentional tremors and poor scholastic performance. His sister has similar complaints. On examination, hepatomegaly is seen. The eye finding is shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with neurological symptoms (intentional tremors and poor scholastic performance) and liver disease (icterus and hepatomegaly) is suggestive of Wilson's disease. 

Wilson's disease is an autosomal-recessive condition caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes for the ATPase that removes copper, preventing its accumulation in the liver and brain.

Clinical features:

  • Liver disease is the most common manifestation in children which can present as hepatomegaly (cirrhosis in advanced stages) with or without splenomegaly, subacute or chronic hepatitis, and acute liver failure.
  • Neurologic features consist of dysarthria, dystonia, rigidity, tremors, and choreiform movements due to copper deposition in the basal ganglia. Psychiatric symptoms encompass personality changes, such as irritability and anger, as well as depression and anxiety. Kayser–Fleischer (KF) rings (deposition of copper in Descement's membrane) are present in 95% of patients with neurological symptoms and absent in half of the young patients with liver-related Wilson disease. After treatment KF ring resolves. Coomb's negative hemolytic anemia may also be seen.
  • Hemolytic anemia can result from the release of copper into the circulation from the liver. Additional manifestations of Wilson's disease comprise renal tubular acidosis, delayed puberty, and osteoarthritis.

Diagnosis is made by the presence of a KF ring and decreased levels of serum copper and ceruloplasmin. Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion is seen. Hepatic copper content greater than 250 μg/g dry weight measured by liver biopsy is the gold standard. 

Copper intake should be restricted to <1 mg/day. Initial treatment involves copper-chelating agents D-penicillamine and trientine with concurrent use of pyridoxine. Penicillamine may worsen neurologic symptoms, so trientine is an alternative. Ammonium tetrathiomolybdate is another chelating agent being investigated for patients with neurologic disease. 

Zinc is used in presymptomatic patients due to its ability to impair the absorption of copper. Liver transplantation is considered in advanced stages. 

Other options:

Option B: Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide (CAG) repeat disorder with an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. It is characterized by involuntary movements known as chorea.

Option C: Glutaric aciduria is an autosomal recessive disease that manifests in the 1st year of life. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glutaryl-CoA dehydrogenase. Clinical features are hypotonia and jitteriness at birth, progressive hyperkinetic movements (dystonia, choreoathetosis), and may have seizures. 

Option D: Hepatitis A is a viral infection transmitted by the fecal-oral route, which is the commonest, parenteral route, and also by sexual transmission. The onset of jaundice is preceded by symptoms like nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and mild fever. Hepatitis A resolves completely but a relapse may occur in a few cases.

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant was brought to you with hypotonia, a weak cough, and tongue fasciculations. A diagnosis of spinal muscular atrophy was made. Which of the following marked regions is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The region marked 1 which shows the anterior horn of the spinal cord is affected in spinal muscular atrophy.

Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is an autosomal recessive pattern disease characterized by progressive degeneration of the motor neurons. It results from a continuation of apoptosis that normally occurs in the embryonal period. This results in extensive neuronal degeneration and gliosis of the anterior horns of the spinal cord and brainstem motor nuclei.

Clinically SMA is classified into four types:

  • SMA type I/ Werdnig-Hoffmann disease
  • SMA type II
  • SMA type III/ Kugelberg-Welander disease
  • SMA type IV

SMA type I is seen before the age of six months. Children present with hypotonia, proximal muscle weakness, frog-leg posture, and tongue fasciculations. Involvement of the intercostal respiratory muscles causes a paradoxical abdominal breathing pattern and weak cough. Deep tendon reflexes are usually absent. It should be kept as one of the differential diagnoses for floppy infant syndrome.

SMA type II is seen between the age of 6-18 months. Children present with developmental delay, scoliosis, speech, and deglutition problems.

The proximal muscles involving the shoulder girdle are affected in SMA type III. Muscle hypertrophy might be present rather than atrophy.

SMA type IV (adult phenotype) presents with mild muscle weakness in the second or third decade of life. 

The gold standard for diagnosis is testing for SMN1 (survival motor neuron) gene deletion/ mutation. Supportive therapy enabling the patient to be maximally functionally independent is the mainstay in management.

questions.text: A 1.5-year-old child is brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, body temperature of less than 37 degrees, cough, and cold. On examination, the respiratory rate was 46/min, and there were no chest retractions. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Administer IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

questions.solution:
This child with a respiratory rate of 46 breaths/min has tachypnea/fast breathing without any danger signs has pneumonia according to IMNCI guidelines. The next best step of management is to administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home.

The treatment for pneumonia for a child between 2 months and 5 years of age is oral amoxicillin and home care advice.

The revised classification of acute respiratory infections is simplified to include only two categories of pneumonia:

  • Cough and cold, no pneumonia - requires home remedy
  • Pneumonia - with fast breathing and/or chest indrawing, which requires home therapy with oral amoxicillin.
  • Severe pneumonia - pneumonia with any general danger sign, which requires a referral and injectable therapy. 

 Danger signs:

  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions, lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

Tachypnea or Fast breathing is defined based on the age and respiratory rate:

Age of child Rate
<2 months 60 breaths/min
2-12 months 50 breaths/min
1-5 years 40 breaths/min

questions.text: An 8-month-old child with acute diarrhea is being treated with oral rehydration solution (ORS).  Which of the following is correct regarding zinc supplementation in this child?
questions.solution:
An 8-month-old child being treated for acute diarrhea should be supplemented with oral zinc at 20 mg/day for 10-14 days.

Zinc administration for diarrhea management can significantly reduce mortality and hospital admission. In addition, it improves diarrhea recovery rates and reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials.

Zinc supplementation is usually done for 10 to 14 days. The dosage is age-dependent as follows:

Age <6 months: 10 mg/day

Age >6 months:  20 mg/day

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: Which of the following has the least risk of perinatal transmission?
questions.solution:
Rubella has the least risk of perinatal transmission. 

Rubella or German measles has an intrauterine transmission that causes serious infection in pregnancy which results in abortions or severe fetal defects if infection occurs in the first trimester. The classical triad of congenital rubella syndrome is deafness, cataract, and congenital heart disease.

Other options- 

Option A: Herpes simplex infection can be acquired in utero, intrapartum/perinatally, or during the neonatal period. The intrauterine infection causes skin vesicles, eye findings (chorioretinitis, keratoconjunctivitis), and microcephaly/hydranencephaly. Intrapartum infection presents with either:

  • Skin, eye, and mouth disease
  • Encephalitis
  • Disseminated disease with sepsis-like presentation

Option B: Cytomegalovirus, the most common congenital infection with perinatal transmission presents with hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequelae is hearing loss. 

Option D: Hepatitis B virus is associated with significant perinatal transmission. The most important risk factor that determines perinatal transmission is HBeAg.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child is brought to the clinic with a common cold and the parents give a  history of stridor, dyspnea, and intercostal retractions shortly after birth. On examination, you notice that he has biphasic stridor.   What is the most probable etiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
The finding of biphasic stridor in this scenario is highly suggestive of congenital subglottic stenosis.

Congenital subglottic stenosis is the most common cause of biphasic stridor in children. The subglottis is the narrowest part of the upper airway in a child. The symptoms of congenital subglottic stenosis usually present shortly after birth and include biphasic stridor, dyspnea, and suprasternal, intercostal, and diaphragmatic retractions. In this child, edema, and secretions caused by the common cold further narrow the subglottic region, leading to the symptoms.  Abnormal cry, aphonia, or hoarseness occur when the vocal cords are affected. In acquired subglottic stenosis, there is a history of laryngeal insult or prior intubation and symptoms appear 3-4 weeks after the same..

Management includes dilatation and endoscopic laser surgery for grades 1 and 2 subglottic stenosis, and laryngotracheal reconstruction with cartilage graft augmentation in grades III and IV subglottic stenosis. Mitomycin C is used in the management of subglottic stenosis post-operatively, in order to prevent re-stenosis.

Other options:

Option A- Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital anomaly causing stridor in a child. which typically presents with low-pitched, inspiratory stridor which is exacerbated by crying and agitation.

Option C- Croup is caused by the parainfluenza virus, and typically presents with symptoms of fever, barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness of voice. In severe cases, the child might develop respiratory distress with hypoxia and cyanosis.

Option D- Bilateral vocal cord paralysis can also cause stridor in infants and children. Congenital central nervous system lesions such as Chiari malformations and myelomeningoceles can cause bilateral vocal cord paralysis which leads to respiratory distress, high-pitched inspiratory stridor, and a weak cry.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy?
questions.solution:
Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy (CP). It is a feature of lower motor neuron disease.

CP is a static encephalopathy and a disorder of posture and movement often associated with:

  • A deficit in the motor, language, and social milestones
  • Microcephaly is a feature of cerebral palsy because of the insult to the developing brain.
  • Dystonic CP is associated with hypotonia
  • Extrapyramidal CP is associated with ataxia
  • It is an upper motor neuron disease characterized by rigidity and scissoring gait.
  • Spastic CP is the commonest type (65%)

Scissoring gait is a characteristic feature of cerebral palsy as shown in the GIF below-

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of bed-wetting almost twice a week for the past 1 year. A detailed investigation was done to rule out an organic cause. What will be the most effective treatment plan for this child?

choices.text: Bladder training, with reward for delaying micturition during daytime
Bell and pad based classical conditioning

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of nocturnal enuresis. Bell and pad-based classical conditioning is the most effective treatment.

Nocturnal enuresis refers to the occurrence of involuntary urination at night after 5 years of age. It may be a normal phenomenon in children up to 5 years of age.

Treatment for nocturnal enuresis may include:

Behavioral therapy:

  • Classic conditioning with the bell (or buzzer) and pad (alarm) apparatus is the most effective treatment for enuresis.
  • Dryness is achieved in 50% of the cases.
  • Bladder training with encouragement or reward for delaying micturition for increasing times during waking hours is useful but considered inferior to bell and pad.

Pharmacotherapy:

  • Medications should be considered if behavioral therapy has failed, and if enuresis is causing impairment in social, family, and school function.
  • Desmopressin (an antidiuretic) and Reboxetine (a norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor) are commonly used drugs. Reboxetine is considered a safer alternative to imipramine.

Psychotherapy:

  • It is indicated in cases with chronic enuresis, to deal with any coexisting psy­chiatric problems and emotional and family difficulties.

questions.text: Breast milk is superior to cow’s milk because ________

choices.text: Casein is 60% of the protein content
Whey is 70% of the protein content

questions.solution:
Whey constitutes 70-80% of breast milk's protein content. The Whey: Casein ratio in human milk fluctuates between 70:30 and 80:20. This ratio is 20:80 in cow's milk. The high fraction of soluble whey protein in breast milk makes it easily digestible.

The predominant whey protein is α-lactalbumin in human milk and β-globulin in cow milk. Human milk contains amino acids like taurine and cysteine (lacking in cow’s milk), which are necessary for neurotransmission and neuromodulation.

Breast milk is rich in polyunsaturated fat (not saturated fat), which is necessary for myelination. Human breast milk is generally rich in oleic acid and linoleic acid.

Sodium concentration is not high in breast milk. It has a low osmolality, and hence, the solute load on the kidneys is low.

Differences between human milk and cow's milk are shown below:

Nutrient Human milk (per 100 mL) Cow's milk (per 100 mL)
Protein 1.1 g 3.5 g
Calories 67 kcal 73 kcal
Casein 30–40% (rich in whey protein) 80%
Lactose 7.4 g 4.5 g
Fat  3.5 g 4g
Na+ (mEq/L) 6.5 25
K+ (mEq/L) 14 35
Osmolality (mOsm/L) 290 350
calcium/phosphate >2 <2
Vitamin K 1.5 µg 6 µg
Iron 0.29–0.45 mg 0.01-0.38 mg
Vitamin D 0.5-10 IU 0.5-4.5 IU

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her otherwise healthy neonate with the lesion show in image. What would you do?

choices.text: Low dose broad spectrum antibiotic prophylaxis

questions.solution:
Reassure the mother that it is benign as the image shows Epstein Pearls.

Epstein Pearls

  • Are nests of epithelial cells.
  • Appear as whitish/yellowish spots on the hard palate.
  • It may also occur over the tip of Prepuce at 6 o'clock position.
  • Usually, resolve in 3 months.

 No intervention is necessary as it resolves spontaneously and is a benign condition.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: All of the following are the features of Kawasaki disease except:
questions.solution:
Purulent conjunctivitis is not a feature of Kawasaki disease.

Kawasaki disease is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome and is commonly seen in children between 3 months to 5 years of age.

Diagnosis of typical Kawasaki disease is made by fever for 5 or more days along with four of the symptoms listed below:

  • Bilateral conjunctival congestion (non purulent conjunctivitis)
  • Oral changes: erythematous, cracked lips and strawberry tongue
  • Non-suppurative cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Polymorphous rash
  • Changes in extremities: erythema and edema, desquamation of palms and soles.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child undergoes treatment for diarrhoea with hypokalemia but the child does not respond to the treatment appropriately and on examination muscular weakness is noted, What is the most likely cause of treatment failure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with diarrhea, muscular weakness, and hypokalemia not responding to treatment is most likely due to hypomagnesemia.

The major cause of hypomagnesemia in this scenario is severe diarrhoea/gastrointestinal loss which in turn worsens the hypokalemia. In such cases, hypokalemia can not be corrected unless the underlying hypomagnesemia is addressed. 

Treatment failure in hypokalemia due to hypomagnesemia is mediated by two mechanisms:

  • ↓ Magnesium → inhibits Na+/ K+ - ATPase activity → ↓ influx of potassium into the cell → secondary kaliuresis.
  • ↓ Magnesium → decreased block of ROMK (renal outer medullary K+ channel) potassium efflux channels → increased potassium secretion by distal nephron

Therefore in the presence of hypomagnesemia, hypokalemic patients are clinically refractory to potassium supplementation therapy.

Hypokalemia is defined as a plasma concentration of K+ <3.5 meq/L. The following are various causes of hypokalemia:

  • Inadequate intake
    • Diet, potassium-free intravenous fluids, potassium deficient TPN
  • Excessive potassium excretion
    • Hyperaldosteronism
    • Medications 
  • Potassium losses
    • Direct loss of potassium from GI fluid (diarrhea)
    • Renal loss of potassium (to conserve sodium in response to gastric losses) 
  • Metabolic
    • Intracellular potassium shifts from metabolic alkalosis or insulin therapy

Clinical features 

  • Weakness and paralysis
  • Intestinal ileus
  • Risk of atrial and ventricular arrhythmias
  • Broad flat T waves, ST depression, and QT prolongation are most marked when serum K+ <2.7 mmol/L
  • Sodium chloride and bicarbonate retention lead to metabolic alkalosis

Management includes potassium supplementation with concurrent cardiac monitoring. Treat hypomagnesemia by supplementation. High dose propranolol if due to excess sympathetic activity

Other options:

Option B: The clinical features of hyponatremia are predominantly neurological as a result of the development of cerebral edema. Patients usually present with nausea, headache, vomiting, seizure, brainstem herniation, and coma.

Option C: The clinical features of hypermagnesemia are dose-dependent. 

  • >2 mmol/L - vasodilation and neuromuscular blockade.
  • >4 mmol/L - refractory hypotension, progressive weakness leading to respiratory paralysis and coma. Although hypermagnesemia causes muscle weakness, the question asked is the cause of treatment failure in hypokalemia.
  • >10mmol/L - dilated pupils, bradycardia, PR, QRS, and QT prolongation.

Option D: The clinical features of hypernatremia are neurological. The most frequent manifestation is altered mental status ranging from confusion and lethargy to deep coma.

questions.text: A 10-year-old female presents for a routine growth evaluation. Her parents express concerns about her height, noting that she seems shorter than her peers. The father’s height is 180 cm, and the mother’s height is 160 cm.  What will be the mid-parental height for this patient?
questions.solution:
The mid-parental height for a female child with a father who is 180 cm and a mother who is 160 cm tall will be 163.5 cm.

Mid-parental height for a female child = (Mother's height + Father's height) / 2 - 6.5

Calculation :

Mother's height = 160 cm  
Father's height = 180 cm  

Mid-parental height = (160 + 180) / 2 - 6.5 = 163.5 cm

Note: Mid-parental height for a male child = (Mother's height + Father's height) / 2 + 6.5.

questions.text: Riya was found to have a height of more than 95 percentile for her age and an arm-span to height ratio of more than 1.05. On further examination, she had flat feet, mild scoliosis, and long slender fingers. An image of her hands showing two characteristic signs is provided below. What other complications can be expected in this child?
questions.solution:
The given features are suggestive of a diagnosis of Marfan's syndrome. Subluxation of the lens is a known complication. 

Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist.

Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist

Features of Marfan's syndrome (Mnemonic: MARFAN’S)

  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Myopia due to upward dislocation of the lens (bilateral ectopic lentis)
  • Aortic root dilatation, Aortic regurgitation
  • Retinal detachment
  • Fibrillin 1 gene defect: Reduced fibrillin 1 production causing joint laxity
  • Fifteen (Chromosome 15 is involved)
  • Flat feet
  • Arachnodactyly, Astigmatism, Air in lungs (Pneumothorax)
  • Nearsightedness
  • Subluxation of lens, Scoliosis, Speech disorders, Sleep apnea

questions.text: An 8 month-old-child with developmental regression, was brought with repeated epileptic spasms upon arousal. The EEG showed irregular multifocal high-voltage spike and wave activity with a chaotic high-voltage slow background. What does the presentation associate with?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and EEG interpretation referred to as hypsarrythmia is seen in infantile spasms (West syndrome).

West syndrome starts between the ages of 2 and 12 months and consists of a triad of:

  • Infantile spasms (salaam attacks)
  • Developmental regression
  • Hypsarrythmia (abnormal EEG)

West syndrome is best treated with

  • First-line agents: ACTH injections
  • Second-line agents: Vigabatrin
Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with short stature and mental retardation. She also has coarse facial features and delayed skeletal maturation and sexual development. Evaluation of the thyroid reveals elevated TSH, low T4, and atrophic thyroid on ultrasonography. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Myxedematous endemic cretinism is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

Children with myxedematous endemic cretinism present with mental retardation, short stature, coarse facial features, deafness, delayed skeletal maturation, delayed sexual development, and no goiter. Serum TSH is elevated while serum T4 levels are low and ultrasonography shows atrophic thyroid.

Endemic cretinism occurs due to the nutritional deficiency of iodine. It can be neurological cretinism or myxedematous cretinism. Both neurologic and myxedematous types can manifest neurologic symptoms. Cretinism is a condition characterized by irreversible abnormalities in intellectual development. Iodine deficiency is also associated with poor school performance in children and recurrent pregnancy loss in women.

Iodine deficiency can be best prevented by using iodized salt and oils. The recommended daily intake of iodine is 40-120 μg for children up to the age of 10 years, and 150 μg for older children and adults. An additional intake of 25 μg and 50 μg is recommended during pregnancy and lactation, respectively.

Other options:

Option B: Neurological cretinism is characterized by deaf-mutism, squint, proximal spasticity and rigidity. Goiter is seen in neurological cretinism. In neurological cretinism skeletal and sexual maturation remains unaffected. Disorders of stance and gait with preservation of vegetative functions, signs of cerebellar or oculomotor disturbance and severe mental deficiency. Myxedematous cretinism is characterized by retarded psychomotor development, severe short stature, coarse facial features and myxedema without deaf-mutism.

Option C: Graves disease includes a triad of hyperthyroidism with goiter, ophthalmopathy, and dermopathy (no mental retardation).

Option D: Pendred syndrome is caused by a mutation in chloride–iodide transporter in the thyroid and cochlea resulting in euthyroid/hypothyroid goiter and sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: What is the sodium content in oral rehydration solution as per WHO?
questions.solution:
The sodium content in WHO ORS is 75 mmol/L. 

Oral rehydration solution (ORS): It is a solution designed to replace fluids and electrolytes in patients with diarrhoea. The 1:1 molar ratio of glucose and sodium in the WHO ORS is based on the principle of glucose-dependent sodium and water absorption in the gut.

Component (Mmol/L) Standard ORS ReSoMal
Glucose 75 (anhydrous) 125
Sodium 75 45
Potassium 20 40
Chloride 65 76
Osmolarity (mosm/L) 245 300

ReSoMal is oral rehydration salt or ORS for severely malnourished children. It is used in in-patient centres for the treatment of children with severe acute malnutrition. ReSoMal contains more glucose (125 mmol/L) and a lower amount of sodium (45 mmol/L) than the standard WHO-ORS. Other homemade fluids containing salt are also recommended to improve hydration in children.

Drinks sweetened with sugar, carbonated beverages, commercial fruit juices, and sweetened tea cause osmotic diarrhea and hypernatremia and are dangerous in patients with diarrhoea. Fluids with stimulant diuretic or purgative effects such as coffee, medicinal tea with infusions, etc. should also be avoided.

Related Pearl: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

Sodium  75  45
Potassium  20  40
Chloride  65  70
Citrate  10  7
Magnesium  ---  3
Zinc  --- 0.3

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presents with short stature. On examination, his upper segment/lower segment ratio is 0.8:1. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Upper segment to lower segment ratio (U/L) less than 1 indicates spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia.

The upper segment to lower segment (U/L) ratio in this child is 0.8. In normal development, the U/L ratio is 1 in children more than 7 years.

The lower segment(L) is defined as the length from the symphysis pubis to the floor. The upper segment(U) is measured by subtracting the lower segment from the height.

The U/L ratio is

  • 1.7 at birth
  • 1.3 at 3 years
  • 1 after 7 years
  • 0.9 in adults

High U/L ratio:

  • Rickets
  • Achondroplasia (short limb dwarfism)
  • Turner syndrome
  • Untreated congenital hypothyroidism

Low U/L ratio:

  • Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia
  • Marfan syndrome
  • Morquio syndrome
  • Vertebral anomalies

questions.text: By what age is the milestone shown in the image typically attained?
questions.solution:
The milestone shown in the image is a mature pincer grasp, which is seen at the age of 12 months. It is identified as a mature pincer grasp as the object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

Developmental progression of the grasp:

  • At 6 months, the infant reaches and holds a larger object in a crude manner using the ulnar aspect of his hand (Ulnar palmar grasp). At 8-9 months, the object is grasped by the radial side of the palm (radial palmar grasp).
  • At 9 months, the immature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the adducted thumb and the extended index finger.
  • At 12 months, the mature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to her paediatrician for routine well-child care. Her physical examination is normal except for a systolic murmur and a widely split second heart sound that does not vary with respiration. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An atrial septal defect (ASD) is the most likely diagnosis due to the characteristic finding of the widely split second heart sound that is fixed during all phases of respiration.

Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found.

Other options:

  • In ventricular septal defect (VSD) – Wide variable splitting of S2 which is masked by the pansystolic murmur.
  • In patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) – first sound is accentuated and S2 is narrowly or paradoxically split.
  • In coarctation of aorta – first sound is accentuated, S2 is normally split with a loud aortic component.
